content.question: What is a VOLMET broadcast?

options.A: Provision, as appropriate, of current METAR, SPECI, TAF and SIGMET by means of continuous and repetitive voice broadcast.
options.B: Information issued by a meteorological watch office concerning the occurrence or expected occurrence of specified enroute weather phenomena which may affect the safety of aircraft operations.
options.C: That part of an ATIS which is concerned to meteorological information.
options.D: Weather information transmitted continuously via radio (special broadcast), containing weather information for one airport.

key_points: ICAO Annex 3 Chapter 1 VOLMET
Meteorological information for aircraft in flight
Data link-VOLMET (D-VOLMET)
learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 3 Chapter 1 VOLMET. Meteorological information for aircraft in flight. Data link-VOLMET (D-VOLMET). Provision of current aerodrome routine meteorological reports (METAR) and aerodrome special meteorological reports (SPECI), aerodrome forecasts (TAF), SIGMET, special air-reports not covered by a SIGMET and, where available, AIRMET via data link. VOLMET broadcast. Provision, as appropriate, of current METAR, SPECI, TAF and SIGMET by means of continuous and repetitive voice broadcasts.

content.question: During flight planning, information about the existence and severity of turbulence aloft can be found on the appropriate..

key_points: Significant Weather Charts are visual presentations of significant weather phenomena for a given geographical region
SIGWX charts are issued by World Area Forecast Centers (WAFC) every six hours (at 00:00, 06:00, 12:00 and 18:00 UTC) as forecast charts to a fixed time specified on the chart

In accordance with ICAO Annex 3, the following weather phenomena have to be shown on a Significant Weather (SIGWX) Chart if present in the chart coverage area: A) thunderstorms (indicate moderate/severe turbulence/icing), B) tropical cyclone, C) severe squall lines, D) moderate or severe turbulence (in cloud or clear air), E) moderate or severe icing, F) widespread sandstorm / dust storm, G) for FL100 to FL250, clouds associated with a) to f), H) above FL250, cumulonimbus cloud associated with a) to f), I) surface position of well-defined convergence zones, J) surface positions, speed and direction of movement of frontal systems when associated with significant en-route weather phenomena, K) tropopause heights (tropopause level, tropopause high, tropopause low), L) jet streams, M) volcanic eruptions producing ash clouds of significance to aircraft operations, including those producing only steam
learning.explanation: Significant Weather Charts are visual presentations of significant weather phenomena for a given geographical region. SIGWX charts are issued by World Area Forecast Centers (WAFC) every six hours (at 00:00, 06:00, 12:00 and 18:00 UTC) as forecast charts to a fixed time specified on the chart. In accordance with ICAO Annex 3, the following weather phenomena have to be shown on a Significant Weather (SIGWX) Chart if present in the chart coverage area: A) thunderstorms (indicate moderate/severe turbulence/icing), B) tropical cyclone, C) severe squall lines, D) moderate or severe turbulence (in cloud or clear air), E) moderate or severe icing, F) widespread sandstorm / dust storm, G) for FL100 to FL250, clouds associated with a) to f), H) above FL250, cumulonimbus cloud associated with a) to f), I) surface position of well-defined convergence zones, J) surface positions, speed and direction of movement of frontal systems when associated with significant en-route weather phenomena, K) tropopause heights (tropopause level, tropopause high, tropopause low), L) jet streams, M) volcanic eruptions producing ash clouds of significance to aircraft operations, including those producing only steam.

learning.explanation: As we can see, position "A" is located in the warm sector of the polar front depression. key_points: VOLMET
Meteorological information for aircraft in flight
Meteorological information about multiple aerodromes in a certain region is sent to aircraft during flight by a pre-recorded voice broadcast, called VOLMET
learning.explanation: VOLMET. Meteorological information for aircraft in flight. Meteorological information about multiple aerodromes in a certain region is sent to aircraft during flight by a pre-recorded voice broadcast, called VOLMET. It is a continuous automated voice message about actual weather conditions and forecasts. VOLMET broadcast on HF consist of weather messages such as METAR, SPECI and TREND as well as (based on regional agreements) TAF and SIGMET. Therefore, its content is similar to these messages.

Which of the following weather conditions would be expected at Ellinikon International airport (LGAT) at around 14:50 UTC?

key_points: Ellinikon International airport (LGAT) - is located in a High Pressure System area
In an anticyclone (high pressure) the winds tend to be light (evidenced by the widely spaced isobars) and blow in a clockwise direction (in the northern hemisphere)
Also, the air is descending, which reduces the formation of cloud and leads to light winds and settled weather conditions
learning.explanation: Ellinikon International airport (LGAT) - is located in a High Pressure System area. In an anticyclone (high pressure) the winds tend to be light (evidenced by the widely spaced isobars) and blow in a clockwise direction (in the northern hemisphere). Also, the air is descending, which reduces the formation of cloud and leads to light winds and settled weather conditions. ANTICYCLONIC WEATHER Cloud - None except on the edge of the anticyclone. Precipitation - None. Visibility - Generally moderate with haze Temperature - Dependent on type. Winds - Light. => This is perfectly described by the following METAR: "21002KT 5000 HZ SCT040 29/16 Q1026 NOSIG=" The fact that we will most likely experience light winds, rules out two of the options: "23018G35KT 9999 SCT035 10/04 Q0988 NOSIG="; and "26014KT 8000 BKN090 17/12 Q1009 BECMG 4000 RA=" "16002KT 0200 R33L/0600N FG VV001 12/12 Q1031 BECMG 0800=" INCORRECT. Moderate visibility can be expected, which rules out this. Furthermore, we can expect winds from a southwesterly direction => 160º is very unlikely.

content.question: Which of the following groups of conditions requires a crew to transmit a special air-report?

options.A: Volcanic ash cloud; isolated thunderstorms; moderate or severe sandstorms.
options.B: Severe turbulence; widespread thunderstorms; severe mountain waves.
options.C: Light/moderate aircraft icing; severe turbulence; embedded thunderstorms.
options.D: Heavy wind shears; light or moderate aircraft icing; moderate or severe turbulence.

key_points: Volcanic ash cloud; isolated thunderstorms; moderate or severe sandstorms
(wrong because "isolated" TS is not correct) Severe turbulence; widespread thunderstorms; severe mountain waves
(correct answer) Light/Moderate aircraft icing; severe turbulence; embedded thunderstorms
learning.explanation: Volcanic ash cloud; isolated thunderstorms; moderate or severe sandstorms. (wrong because "isolated" TS is not correct) Severe turbulence; widespread thunderstorms; severe mountain waves. (correct answer) Light/Moderate aircraft icing; severe turbulence; embedded thunderstorms. (wrong because "light" icing is not correct) Heavy wind shears; light or moderate aircraft icing; moderate or severe turbulence. (wrong because "light" icing is not correct) A special air-report (ARS) can be made by any aircraft, when encountering or observing weather phenomena that may affect safety as for example severe turbulence, icing or mountain waves, hail, cumolonimbus clouds, squall-lines, thunderstorms, sandstorms, volcanic ash cloud, volcanic activity or phenomena regarding SIGMET. ICAO Annex 3 Table A4-2. Template for the special air-report (downlink) Condition prompting the issuance of a special air-report (M) SEV TURB (see also note 2) or SEV ICE or SEV MTW or TS GR (see also note 3) or TS (see also note 3) or HVY SS (see also note 4) or VA CLD [FL nnn/nnn] or VA (see also note 5) [MT nnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnn] Notes.— 1. The time of occurrence to be reported in accordance with Table A4-1. 2. The turbulence to be reported in accordance with 2.6.3. 3. Obscured, embedded or widespread thunderstorms or thunderstorms in squall lines. 4. Duststorm or sandstorm. 5. Pre-eruption volcanic activity or a volcanic eruption. 2.6.3 Special air-reports Special air-reports on turbulence shall be made during any phase of the flight whenever the peak value of the cube root of EDR exceeds 0.7. The special air-report on turbulence shall be made with reference to the 1-minute period immediately preceding the observation. Both the average and peak value of turbulence shall be observed. The average and peak values shall be reported in terms of the cube root of EDR. Special air-reports shall be issued every minute until such time as the peak values of the cube root of EDR fall below 0.7. Note: EDR = Eddy Dissipation Rate (represents the intensity of turbulence)

content.question:
Below is the forecast for the destination of a flight whose ETA is 20:30 UTC.
TAF YUDO 120600Z 1212/1306 17010KT 3000 SCT005 BECMG 1218/1220 VRB03KT BCFG NSC TEMPO 1220/1222 0300 FG VV001= What can be said about the destination airport at 20:30 UTC if ILS minima 350 m RVR, 200 ft Decision Height are being considered?

options.A: There is the possibility that the weather conditions may be below the applicable landing minima.
options.B: The weather conditions will be above the applicable landing minima until 22:00 UTC because the weather change is not completed before this time.
options.C: The weather conditions will be above the applicable landing minima because the decrease in visibility below the ILS minima will be a little bit later than 20:30 UTC.
options.D: The weather conditions will be above the applicable landing minima throughout the forecast period because 300m of visibility corresponds to at least 900m RVR.

key_points: TAF YUDO 120600Z 1212/1306 17010KT 3000 SCT005 BECMG 1218/1220 VRB03KT BCFG NSC TEMPO 1220/1222 0300 FG VV001= Period of validity is stated as 12:00 UTC day 12 until 06:00 UTC day 13 (1212/1306)
Initial weather conditions are forecasted to be: 17010KT = wind 170º at 10 kt 3000 = visibility 3000 m SCT005 = scattered clouds at 500 ft above the airport
A change of permanent character is expected to occur on day 12 at any time between 18:00 and 20:00 (BECMG 1218/1220)
learning.explanation: TAF YUDO 120600Z 1212/1306 17010KT 3000 SCT005 BECMG 1218/1220 VRB03KT BCFG NSC TEMPO 1220/1222 0300 FG VV001= Period of validity is stated as 12:00 UTC day 12 until 06:00 UTC day 13 (1212/1306). Initial weather conditions are forecasted to be: 17010KT = wind 170º at 10 kt 3000 = visibility 3000 m SCT005 = scattered clouds at 500 ft above the airport. A change of permanent character is expected to occur on day 12 at any time between 18:00 and 20:00 (BECMG 1218/1220). After the change occurs, the following conditions are to be expected: VRB03KT – wind variable at 3 kts. BCFG – patches of fog NSC – no significant clouds Next changes expected are of temporary character (TEMPO 1220/1222) => which means that the listed conditions can occur on day 12 at any time between 20:00 and 22:00 UTC, but are not of permanent character and may occur momentarily, for a max of 1h at each time. Thereafter, the conditions will revert back to how they were previously. 0300 = visibility 300 m FG - fog VV001 – vertical visibility 100 ft. The change of temporary character indicates that between 20 UTC and 22 UTC, the visibility may deteriorate to 300 m (+ forecasted fog). This may occur before 2030 ETA – therefore, we must be prepared for the visibility to be already below our stated landing minima of 350 m at that time. Note: RVR usually exceeds the reported prevailing visibility, however, we cannot rely on this being the case and we must assume the worst.

TC ADVISORY
DTG: 20130712/1900Z
TCAC: MIAMI
TC: DORIAN
TC ADVISORY NR: 2013/4
OBS PSN: 12/1800Z N2706 W07306
MOV: NW 18KT
INTST CHANGE: INTSF
C: 962 HPA
MAX WIND: 030KT
According to the tropical cyclone advisory above, which of the following statements are correct?
1. Pressure 962 hpa
2. Cyclone will increase in strength
3. Max wind surface 30 MPS
4. Max Wind at 24 h 27 MPS
5. New Message will be at 2000z
6. Occurs 15 March

key_points: Note: This question has been created from incomplete feedback
It is possible that the official TC Advisory provides further information, making another statement correct
The current correct option is correct for the present TC Advisory
learning.explanation: Note: This question has been created from incomplete feedback. It is possible that the official TC Advisory provides further information, making another statement correct. The current correct option is correct for the present TC Advisory. Please let us know if you come across this question in your official exam. "Pressure 962 hpa" is correct, "C: 962 HPA" "Cyclone will increase in strength" is correct, "INTST CHANGE: INTSF" = Intensifying. "Max wind surface 30 MPS" is incorrect, "MAX WIND: 030KT" maximum wind is reported in knots. In this case, max wind equals 30 kt, which is approximately equal to 15 m/s (meters per second). "Max Wind at 24 h 27 MPS" is incorrect, it's not specified if Max Wind at 24 h 27 MPS. "New Message will be at 2000z" is incorrect, it's not specified New Message will be at 2000z "Occurs 15 March" is incorrect, the date of the message is 12th July 2013, not 15 March. Tropical Cyclone Advisory Information - Form of the code 1- Identification group: The report starts with the term "TC ADVISORY", which indicates that it is a tropical cyclone advisory. 2- Date and time of the issuance (abbreviated as "DTG"): The year, month, day, hours and minutes of the issuance are reported in UTC as "yyyymmdd/GGggZ" ⇒ 20130712/1900z 12th of july 2013 at 1900z. 3- Name of the TCAC (abbreviated as "TCAC"): The name of the TCAC that issued the report is given in a free text form ⇒ MIAMI 4- Name of the tropical cyclone (abbreviated as "TC"): The name, or number of the cyclone is given ⇒ DORIAN 5- Advisory number (abbreviated as NR): This number starts with "01" and increase with each cyclone in the season ⇒ 2013/4 6- Observed position of the centre (abbreviated as "OBS PSN"): Geographical coordinates of the centre of the tropical cyclone given in degrees and minutes ⇒ N2706 W07306 7- Direction and speed of the movement (abbreviated as "MOV"): If the tropical ccylone moves slowly (moving at a speed lower than 3 kt), or it is stationary (moving at a speed lower than 1 kt), the abbreviations SLW or STNR are used, respectively ⇒ NW 18 KT 8 - Intensity change (abbreviated as "INTST CHANGE"): This appears to be optional. If there is a definite change in intensity, it will be shown here; INTSF, NC, etc ⇒INTSF 9- Atmospheric pressure of the centre (abbreviated as "C"): Given in units of hPa ⇒ 963 hPa 10- Maximum surface wind (abbreviated as "MAX WIND") The maximum value of the surface wind near the centre over a 10 minute time period ⇒ 30 KT 11- Forecast of the position of the centre and maximum wind (abbreviated as "FCST PSN" and "FCST MAX WIND"): This information is reported 6, 12, 18 and 24 hours after the time of observation ⇒ Not present on this extract 12- Remarks (abbreviated as "RMK") ⇒ Not present on this extract 13- The code "NXT MSG EXP" indicates the date of the issuance of the next advisory ⇒ Not present on this extract The report ends with an equal sign.

Initial weather conditions are forecasted to be: VRB05KT = wind variable 5 kt 4000 = visibility 4000 m BR = mist SCT005 = scattered clouds at 500 ft above the airport. OVC013 = overcast layer at 1300 ft A change of permanent character is expected to occur on day 28 at any time between 13:00 and 14:00 (BECMG 2813/2814) and there is only a 40% probability that they will occur (PROB40). After the change occurs, the following conditions are to be expected: 9000 = visibility 9000 m SHRA = showers of rain OVC015 = overcast layer at 1500 ft Next changes expected are of temporary character (TEMPO 2814/2816) => which means that the listed conditions can occur on day 28 at any time between 14:00 and 16:00 UTC, but are not of permanent character and may occur momentarily, for a max of 1h at each time. Thereafter, the conditions will revert back to how they were previously. VRB15G25KT = wind variable 15 kt gusting to a maximum of 25 kt 1600 = visibility 1600 m TSRA = thunderstorms and moderate rain OVC010CB = overcast layer at 1000 ft and Cumulonimbus Another change of permanent character is expected to occur later on day 28 at any time between 16:00 and 18:00 (BECMG 2816/2818). 26010KT = wind at 260º at 10 kt Another change of permanent character is expected to occur later on day 28 at any time between 21:00 and 22:00 (BECMG 2821/2822). CAVOK => At 1500 UTC, we might be affected by the change of permanent character occurring between 13:00 and 14:00 UTC => OVC015 or the change of temporary character occurring between 14:00 and 16:00 UTC => OVC010CB. Since the question asks for lowest possible cloud base and not the most probable one, the correct option is 1000 ft.

content.question: When a pilot reports windshear during approach, the ... should be included in the message:

key_points: AIR TRAFFIC SERVICES (ATS) REPORTING OF WIND SHEAR 5

11 The relay of air-reports of wind shear to other aircraft and the provision of wind shear information to pilots in general are covered in the Procedures for Air Navigation Services — Air Traffic Management (Doc 4444, PANS-ATM), 6
learning.explanation: AIR TRAFFIC SERVICES (ATS) REPORTING OF WIND SHEAR 5.3.11 The relay of air-reports of wind shear to other aircraft and the provision of wind shear information to pilots in general are covered in the Procedures for Air Navigation Services — Air Traffic Management (Doc 4444, PANS-ATM), 6.4.1, 6.6 and 7.3.1.2.2. The air-report should be relayed with content unchanged, although additional relevant factual information missing from the original report should be added if known (e.g. aircraft type, runway). The reports should be relayed using the following standardsequence, the contents depending upon the details of the original report: a) wind shear — identifier; b) aircraft type — added if not included in the original report; c) description of event — no change to the report as received from the pilot; d) height wind shear encountered — no change to the report as received from the pilot; e) phase of flight — no change to the report as received from the pilot; f) runway — added if not included in the original report; g) time of encounter — no change to the report as received from the pilot; and h) MET/operational information — no change to the report as received from the pilot. An example of such a report is as follows: “WIND SHEAR B747 REPORTED STRONG WIND SHEAR AT 300 FT ON APPROACH RWY27 AT 0937 MAX THRUST REQUIRED”

content.question: Runway Visual Range (RVR) is:

options.B: measured with ceilometers alongside the runway.
options.C: reported when meteorological visibility is less than 2 000 m.

key_points: Runway Visual Range (RVR) is the range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings or the light delineating the runway or identifying its centre line
(ICAO Annex 3) The RVR is specific to the runway and its actual lighting system (i
e
learning.explanation: Runway Visual Range (RVR) is the range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings or the light delineating the runway or identifying its centre line. (ICAO Annex 3) The RVR is specific to the runway and its actual lighting system (i.e. can be different for different runways of the same airport at the same time), where visibility only refers to the general range an object or light can be seen in the current conditions. ICAO Aerodrome Meteorological Observation and Forecast Study Group (AMOFSG) A COMPARISON OF RVR AND VISIBILITY REPORTS 2. Discussion Previous studies have shown that the reported value of RVR is typically higher than the associated visibility value. In fact, empirical rules can be used to relate values of visibility with the most probable value of RVR (see IP3 from the sixth meeting of this study group). These findings are consistent with the fact that the assessment of RVR takes advantage of high intensity runway lights while the visibility assessment is based upon lights of moderate intensity Note: "measured with ceilometers alongside the runway." INCORRECT. RVR is measured with transmissometers. A ceilometer is a device that uses a laser or other light source to determine the height of a cloud ceiling or cloud base "reported when meteorological visibility is less than 2 000 m." INCORRECT. RVR is reported when the visibility decreases below 1500 m.

content.question: Which of the following gridded forecasts do the WAFCs prepare for flight-planning purposes?

options.A: Geostrophic wind speed, vertical extent of CBs, humidity and CAT.

learning.explanation: 050.10.02.04.02: Explain that world area forecast centres prepare global sets of gridded forecasts for flight planning purposes (upper wind, temperature, humidity). content.question: Which instrument is used to measure atmospheric humidity?

key_points: Atmospheric humidity can be measured using a psychrometer, a dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer or an electrical hygrometer
The psychrometer and the dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer use two thermometers to measure relative humidity; one measures the dry-bulb temperature and the other measures the wet-bulb temperature
The wet-bulb thermometer contains water in the base that evaporates and absorbs heat which decreases the temperature reading
learning.explanation: Atmospheric humidity can be measured using a psychrometer, a dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer or an electrical hygrometer. The psychrometer and the dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer use two thermometers to measure relative humidity; one measures the dry-bulb temperature and the other measures the wet-bulb temperature. The wet-bulb thermometer contains water in the base that evaporates and absorbs heat which decreases the temperature reading. To determine the relative humidity, the temperatures are taken from the dry-bulb thermometer and the temperature difference between the wet and dry bulb thermometers. Note: "Anemometer" is used to measure wind speed. "Nephoscope" is used to measure the movement of clouds. "Transmissometer" is used to determine visibility and runway visual range.

learning.explanation: QNH - barometric pressure at the airfield (QFE), converted to mean sea level (MSL) using the ISA temperature at the airfield and the ISA pressure lapse rate. In other words, it is the pressure set on the subscale of the altimeter so that the instrument indicates its height above sea level. When on the aerodrome with QNH set the altimeter will read aerodrome elevation. QNH is always a whole number, without any decimal places, and is always rounded down.

content.question: Which kind of meteorological information is normally transmitted in an ATIS?

key_points: The Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is a continuous broadcast of current aerodrome weather and other aerodrome information
The purpose of the ATIS is to improve controller effectiveness and to reduce congestion on busy ground, tower and approach frequencies by automatically transmitting on a discrete VHF radio frequency

Pilots departing from or arriving at aerodromes which offer ATIS are encouraged to listen to the ATIS broadcast and to notify air traffic control, on initial contact, that they have received the ATIS broadcast, by passing the phonetic alphabet code letter by which all ATIS broadcasts are identified
learning.explanation: The Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is a continuous broadcast of current aerodrome weather and other aerodrome information. The purpose of the ATIS is to improve controller effectiveness and to reduce congestion on busy ground, tower and approach frequencies by automatically transmitting on a discrete VHF radio frequency. Pilots departing from or arriving at aerodromes which offer ATIS are encouraged to listen to the ATIS broadcast and to notify air traffic control, on initial contact, that they have received the ATIS broadcast, by passing the phonetic alphabet code letter by which all ATIS broadcasts are identified. At some aerodromes there will be a separate ATIS broadcast for departure and arrival. In order to free up air traffic VHF communication frequencies, some aerodromes transmit the ATIS information on the voice channel of a VOR beacon located at the aerodrome. ATIS will be broadcast in plain language and will contain some or all of the following information, if applicable. Aerodrome name. ATIS sequence designator or information code. Time of observation. Runway in use and status. Surface wind in knots and referenced to magnetic north. Visibility and RVR. Present weather. Significant cloud. Temperature and dew point. Altimeter setting. Transition level. Type of approach expected. And finally any warnings pertinent to flight operations.

content.question: To best detect low cumulus clouds in summer, which satellite imagery should be used?

key_points: Visual Images
Although visual photography may be easy to interpret, it suﬀers the disadvantage of not being available continuously, due to lack of sunlight at night
Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black Infrared (IR)
learning.explanation: Visual Images. Although visual photography may be easy to interpret, it suﬀers the disadvantage of not being available continuously, due to lack of sunlight at night. Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black Infrared (IR). Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image. To get a clear picture of the weather you should analyse both the IR and visible images. If both images are bright in the same area => very likely that you can find a very high and thick cloud with high convective activity over that area. If you get cloud returns on a visible imagery but not on an IR image => most likely a low cloud or fog. If you get a white return on an IR imagery, along with a translucent whitish layer on a visible imagery => it is most likely a high wispy cloud - a thin layer of cirrostratus.

content.question: The term CAVOK is used when weather conditions are:

key_points: The code CAVOK is frequently used in the METAR code, being the abbreviation for “cloud, ceiling and visibility are OK
” If CAVOK is used, it will replace the visibility, RVR, weather and cloud groups
There are four criteria which must be met in order for CAVOK to appear in the METAR
learning.explanation: The code CAVOK is frequently used in the METAR code, being the abbreviation for “cloud, ceiling and visibility are OK.” If CAVOK is used, it will replace the visibility, RVR, weather and cloud groups. There are four criteria which must be met in order for CAVOK to appear in the METAR. These are: the visibility must be 10 kilometers or more; the height of the lowest cloud must be no less than 5000 ft, or the level of highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater; there must be no cumulonimbus or ‘towering cumulus’ (TCU) present; there must be no significant weather at or in the vicinity of the aerodrome. Note: Minimum Sector Altitude is the lowest altitude that may be used under emergency conditions which will provide a minimum clearance of 1 000 ft above all objects located in an area contained within a sector of a circle of 25 NM radius centered on a radio navigation aid. 9999 Visibility of 10 Km or more NSC No Significant Cloud NSW No Significant Weather

learning.explanation: The flight path from Lomé (L) to Nairobi (N) traverses an area with intermittent occurrences of CBs (cumulonimbus clouds) labeled as OCNL (occasional) and ISOL (isolated). As a result, the extent of cloud coverage in this region is below 75% of the total area in question. Isolated (ISOL). Used if an area consists of individual features which are forecast to affect an area with a maximum spatial coverage of between less than 50% of the area concerned. These features can be easily avoided. Occasional (OCNL). Used if an area consists of well-separated features, which are forecast to affect an area with a maximum spatial coverage of between 50% and 75% of the area concerned. These features can be avoided by pilots. Frequent (FRQ). Used if within a particular area there is little separation between phenomena, and the spatial coverage is greater than 75% of the area forecast to be affected by that phenomenon (used for convective types only). These features will be difficult to avoid. The following are some of the abbreviations associated with CB (and TS) with their meaning: ISOL, (isolated) - individual OCNL, (occasional) - well-separated FRQ, (frequent) - little or no separation between CB SQL, (squall) - a line of CB with little or no separation

content.question: Considering gridded forecast products, what does having gridded data on CBs and turbulence allow?

options.A: Passengers can view the weather on in-flight entertainment systems so will better understand the reasons for any delay or re-routing.
options.B: The only reason to present data in this way is that it can be filed and easily retrieved for accident investigation purposes.
options.C: Crews will receive advance warning about each and every type of hazardous weather conditions ahead.
options.D: The data can be displayed in a variety of forms to aid crews in visualising flight hazards.

key_points: Numerical weather prediction (NWP) uses mathematical models of the atmosphere and oceans to predict the weather based on current weather conditions
The gridded forecasts are part of the NWP and these solve most of the traditional forecast limitations
For example, a gridded CB forecast contains all convective clouds producing precipitation, whereas a SIGWX contains only areas of isolated or occasional embedded CB
learning.explanation: Numerical weather prediction (NWP) uses mathematical models of the atmosphere and oceans to predict the weather based on current weather conditions. The gridded forecasts are part of the NWP and these solve most of the traditional forecast limitations. For example, a gridded CB forecast contains all convective clouds producing precipitation, whereas a SIGWX contains only areas of isolated or occasional embedded CB. Gridded forecasts are available at upper height, between FL050 and FL630. These are for the following atmospheric variables: Air temperature Humidity Wind direction and speed Temperature of the tropopause Wind speed, wind direction and flight level of maximum wind Geopotential altitude of the flight levels Cumulonimbus clouds, turbulence and icing. This data can be integrated into, and visualised by, flight planning software and play a key part in the decision making process. The data is relayed from pilot reports/aircraft.

content.question: RVR is reported in steps of _____ when the RVR is less than 400 m, and _____ when the RVR is 400 m or more but less than 800 m, and _____ when the RVR is 800 m or more.

key_points: Runway visual range (RVR)
The range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings or the lights delineating the runway or identifying its centre line
In METARs, the RVR values are prefixed by the letter “R”, followed by the runway number for which the RVR value applies and the actual RVR value
learning.explanation: Runway visual range (RVR). The range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings or the lights delineating the runway or identifying its centre line. In METARs, the RVR values are prefixed by the letter “R”, followed by the runway number for which the RVR value applies and the actual RVR value. According to ICAO Annex 3, RVR is reported in steps of 25 m when the RVR is between 0 - 375 m (less than 400 m), 50 m when the RVR is between 400 - 750 m (less than 800 m) and 100 m when the RVR is between 800 - 2000 m (800 m or more).

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The dark area (around 60 NM / 330°) on this weather radar return showing is:

key_points: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through
Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs
The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation
learning.explanation: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through. Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs. The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation. In simple words, Radar attenuation (shadowing) is simply the absorption or reflection of radar signals as the radar pulse penetrates an area of precipitation, preventing that radar from detecting any additional cells that lie behind the first storm. Tip for avoiding shadows: To accurately interpret your radar returns, aim the tilt on your radar down far enough to paint the ground, then look for returns. If you see a potential shadow (a dark, blank area), look for a cell in front of the shadow. If you see a storm before the shadow, avoid it. If you don’t see any storm cells in front of the dark area, it’s probably not a shadow, but may be a large lake or a tall mountain (equally disturbing, depending on your altitude).
